questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreased hearing in his right ear for the past 4 months. During this period, he has also had multiple episodes of dizziness and a constant ringing noise in his right ear. Over the past 5 weeks, he has also noticed scant amounts of right-sided ear discharge. He has a history of multiple ear infections since childhood that were treated with antibiotics. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows a white pearly mass behind the right tympanic membrane. Placing a 512 Hz tuning fork in the center of the forehead shows lateralization to the right ear. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical quinolone antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin) are indicated in the treatment of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) or uncomplicated otitis externa. Although both conditions may also lead to hearing loss, otorrhea, and tinnitus, the patient's otoscopic finding of a pearly mass in the middle ear indicates a more aggressive condition. Topical antibiotics would not be helpful.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the middle ear

The tympanic membrane is completely perforated and the tympanic cavity can be seen. The mucous membrane of the tympanic cavity is edematous and covered by clear secretions.

These findings are diagnostic of chronic suppurative otitis media, which can develop from acute otitis media with tympanic membrane perforation.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy can be used in the treatment of jugulotympanic paragangliomas. Jugulotympanic paragangliomas frequently manifest as pulsatile tinnitus with or without conductive hearing loss. However, this patient's description of tinnitus is constant rather than pulsatile. Also, physical examination would more likely reveal a bluish pulsating mass behind the tympanic membrane.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used for the treatment of hearing loss secondary to granulomatosis with polyangiitis. In the early stages, this condition often manifests with symptoms of chronic sinusitis, rhinitis, or otitis media. Although this patient's complaints are consistent with chronic otitis media, granulomatosis with polyangiitis would likely manifest with pneumonia-like symptoms, sinusitis, polychondritis, ocular involvement (e.g., conjunctivitis, diplopia), and/or skin lesions. Also, this condition does not typically manifest with a pearly mass in the middle ear.

D) INCORRECT:

Hearing aids may be useful for many causes of hearing loss (e.g., tympanosclerosis). Tympanosclerosis typically occurs after frequent episodes of otitis media and can also manifest with unilateral conductive hearing loss. On otoscopy, tympanosclerosis would manifest as a flat white lesion rather than a pearly white mass. Hearing aids are not appropriate for a cholesteatoma. If left untreated, the cholesteatoma would likely continue to grow and put the patient at risk for complications.
Image Description:

Otoscopy of a right ear

A white, grape-shaped, calcified plaque (green overlay) is visible in the 3rd quadrant of the tympanic membrane.

This is the typical appearance of tympanosclerosis.

E) CORRECT:

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for cholesteatoma. Spontaneous resolution is rare and complications are common. If left untreated, patients are at risk for serious complications such as erosion of the temporal bone, permanent hearing loss, facial weakness, paralysis of the facial muscles, meningitis, and brain abscesses.

This patient most likely has a secondary acquired cholesteatoma based on his otoscopy finding of a pearly mass in the middle ear. In secondary acquired cholesteatoma, epithelium migrates inwards through a perforated tympanic membrane. The defect in the tympanic membrane often heals and is no longer visible on diagnosis.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the left tympanic membrane.

Encrustation and darkening of the epithelium can be seen in the posterior upper quadrant marginal to the pars flaccida (arrow). The localization and findings indicate a cholesteatoma.
questions.hint: This patient presents with unilateral hearing loss, otorrhea, tinnitus, vertigo, and a past history of multiple ear infections. These symptoms, in combination with lateralization to the affected ear (indicating conductive hearing loss) in Weber test and otoscopic finding of a pearly mass in the middle ear, are indicative of a cholesteatoma.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 42-year-old man comes to the physician with progressive hearing loss for the past year and painless unilateral fluid leakage from the ear for the past month. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). Otoscopic examination shows a brown, irregular mass and partial retraction of the tympanic membrane. The results of an audiogram are shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's hearing loss?

choices.text: Infection of the external ear canal on the right
Accumulation of sebaceous gland secretions on the left
Damage to the organ of Corti on the right
Malignant squamous cell neoplasia on the left
Collection of keratinizing squamous epithelium on the right
Tumor of the vestibular nerve on the left

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection of the external ear canal (otitis externa) on the right can lead to fluid leakage from the right ear and conductive hearing loss on the right, which are seen on this patient's audiogram. However, otitis externa is typically associated with severe ear pain. Otoscopy in this condition would show an erythematous and edematous external ear canal. Furthermore, otitis externa is an acute condition, whereas this patient's presentation indicates a more chronic process.

B) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of cerumen, which is secreted by the sebaceous glands in the auditory canal, can cause cerumen impaction and lead to otorrhea and conductive hearing loss. However, cerumen impaction on the left would result in impaired air conduction of the left ear, whereas this patient's audiogram shows abnormal air conduction on the right side. Furthermore, otoscopy of a cerumen-impacted ear would show obstruction of the external auditory canal by a brownish-yellow, waxy plug; the tympanic membrane would most likely not be visible.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the external auditory canal

The auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.

C) INCORRECT:

Unilateral damage to the organ of Corti can occur, e.g., as a result of labyrinthitis. However, damage to the organ of Corti manifests with sensorineural hearing loss, which would show up on audiometry as an increase in the threshold for both air and bone conduction. Furthermore, patients with labyrinthitis also typically present acutely or subacutely, unlike this patient, who has had progressive hearing loss for the past year, and labyrinthitis is usually associated with tinnitus and/or vertigo.
Image Description:

Pure tone audiogram

Both ears show a parallel decrease of air and bone conduction in the higher frequencies. This finding indicates cochlear or retrocochlear damage (often seen in presbycusis).

D) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the external auditory canal can manifest with otorrhea and conductive hearing loss, as well as otoscopic findings similar to those seen in this patient. However, patients would typically have severe ear pain, which is not seen here, and this patient's audiogram shows conductive hearing loss in the right, not the left ear.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's progressive right-sided conductive hearing loss, painless otorrhea, and irregular mass on otoscopy suggest a cholesteatoma of the right ear. This condition is characterized by keratinizing squamous epithelium growing from the tympanic membrane or the auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa or the mastoid, causing chronic inflammation and erosion of the auditory ossicles. Cholesteatomas can be congenital or acquired. Acquired cholesteatomas can be classified as primary if caused by chronic negative middle ear pressure (due to eustachian tube dysfunction without middle ear infection) or secondary if caused by past injury to the tympanic membrane (typically due to chronic otitis media). The retraction pocket in the tympanic membrane and brown, irregular mass seen in this patient's otoscopy are characteristic of primary acquired cholesteatoma. Secondary acquired cholesteatomas, on the other hand, typically appear as a pearly white mass shining through the intact tympanic membrane.
Image Description:

A cholesteatoma is a collection of keratinizing squamous epithelium that grows from the tympanic membrane or the auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa or mastoid. The presence of abnormal epithelium triggers an inflammatory response that can destroy surrounding structures such as the ossicles.

F) INCORRECT:

Tumors of the vestibulocochlear nerve such as acoustic neuromas can cause unilateral hearing loss, which is seen in this patient. However, a tumor on the left would be evident on an audiogram as sensorineural hearing loss on the left, characteristically showing increased auditory thresholds in both air and bone conduction. This patient's audiogram shows conductive hearing loss in the right ear. Moreover, a tumor of the vestibular nerve would likely cause further symptoms, such as vertigo and tinnitus, and would not explain this patient's otorrhea and otoscopic findings.
questions.hint: This patient's audiogram shows an air-bone gap as a result of an increased auditory threshold in air conduction with normal bone conduction, which is typical for conductive hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman reports a 2-month history of otorrhea and decreased hearing on the left, as well as a long history of frequent bilateral ear infections. She was treated with several sets of tympanostomy tubes as a child.
Otoscopic examination reveals scarring of the right tympanic membrane. The left tympanic membrane is opaque and immobile, with a prominent lateral process of the malleus. Keratinized debris and purulence are evident superiorly, at the pars flaccida.
On follow-up examination, after a 10-day course of topical antibiotics, the left-ear otorrhea has stopped. However, a collection of keratinized debris remains at the superior aspect of the tympanic membrane.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In eustachian-tube dysfunction, the eustachian tube fails to equalize pressure between the middle ear and the atmosphere, resulting in negative middle-ear pressure. This can cause recurrent middle-ear infections requiring myringotomy and tube placement, particularly in children. If the dysfunction persists into adulthood, patients may develop chronic otitis media with tympanic-membrane retraction and cholesteatoma, a collection of keratinized debris that builds up in the retraction pockets.

It is important to recognize cholesteatoma when it develops, because it can become superinfected and/or erode the ossicles. On otoscopy, the tympanic membrane will be retracted and appear concave, with a prominent lateral process of the malleus. In addition, the tympanic membrane may be immobile on pneumatic otoscopy. Patients with cholesteatoma should be referred to an otolaryngologist.

Key learning point: When keratinized debris is evident above the tympanic membrane, the most likely diagnosis is cholesteatoma. Cholesteatomas can erode the ossicles and become superinfected.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic eczematoid otitis externa may be accompanied by white debris in the ear canal, but it clears with treatment, leaving the ear drum normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction may initially be associated with an ear infection, but after the infection and wax are cleared, the ear should look normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Fungal otitis externa is associated with whitish debris in the ear canal. It will not clear with antibiotics or antibacterial ear drops. The external auditory canal would appear inflamed, and the tympanic membrane would not be retracted.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute otitis media does not lead to a buildup of keratinized debris in the ear. The tympanic membrane initially appears bulging and convex; it returns to normal after the infection clears.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents for a hearing evaluation. His mother reports that for the past few months, he has been listening to music and television at higher volumes. His teacher has moved his seat to the front of the classroom because of perceived hearing difficulties. He had middle- ear infections at ages 2 and 3 years. He has been in good health since then and does not have any current ear pain, fevers, or upper respiratory symptoms.
He appears well and is afebrile. His vital signs are within normal limits. The right ear is examined otoscopically (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Foreign bodies are visualized within the ear canal and often obstruct clear visualization of the tympanic membrane. This patient’s lesion is medial to the tympanic membrane, whereas a foreign body would be located lateral to the tympanic membrane.

B) INCORRECT:

Glomus tumors are benign paragangliomas of the middle ear or temporal bone. Glomus tumors within the middle-ear cavity appear as vascular masses and generally manifest with hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. They are generally found in adults and are exceedingly rare in children.

C) CORRECT:

A congenital cholesteatoma should be suspected if there is a white mass behind an intact eardrum (as in this case).

Cholesteatomas are abnormal growths of squamous epithelium and keratin debris within the middle ear and mastoid. They are classified as congenital if the patient has no history of ear surgery and no perforation or retraction of the tympanic membrane. Acquired cholesteatomas usually result from chronic middle-ear disease, typically with associated tympanic membrane retraction or perforation. After recurrent infections or ear surgery, focal retractions of the tympanic membrane may form. The retraction is progressively pulled into the middle ear, forming a large pouch and trapping the epithelium of the tympanic membrane and keratin debris, resulting in the development of the cholesteatoma.

A patient with a suspected cholesteatoma, whether congenital or acquired, should be referred to an otolaryngologist immediately for surgical management. Although cholesteatomas are histologically benign, the growths may enlarge within the middle ear and destroy the ossicles, resulting in conductive hearing loss. Early recognition of cholesteatoma reduces the risk for hearing loss and other complications such as cranial nerve (sixth and seventh) palsies, vertigo, venous thrombosis, and potentially life-threatening infections such as brain abscess and meningitis.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a child who presents with hearing loss and is found to have a white mass behind an intact eardrum is cholesteatoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Tympanosclerosis, a white plaque of calcium and phosphate crystals on the tympanic membrane, may obscure the view of the middle-ear cavity and is usually the result of recurrent otitis media, use of tympanostomy tubes, or both. Tympanosclerosis is a condition of the tympanic membrane, does not occupy the middle ear, and is most commonly considered of no clinical consequence; it very rarely leads to hearing loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic suppurative otitis media is defined as a perforated tympanic membrane with drainage for 6 to 12 weeks. This patient’s tympanic membrane is intact.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 42 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: clinic
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My hearing is getting worse and I have liquid coming out of my ear.” 
History of Present Illness:

1-year history of progressive hearing loss

1-month history of painless unilateral fluid leakage from the right ear
no dizziness or ringing in ears

Past Medical History:
generalized anxiety disorder
Medications:
citalopram
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Psychosocial History:
has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


37.1°C(98.8°F)
65/min
14/min
135/80 mm Hg
-
182 cm(6 ft 0 in)
70 kg(154 lb)
20.9 kg/m2




Appearance: sitting in a chair, comfortable
HEENT: left ear canal with no erythema, discharge, or swelling and tympanic membrane is reflective of light; right ear with otorrhea and a brown, irregular mass and partial retraction of the tympanic membrane

Neurologic: no abnormalities; cranial nerves are grossly intact

Diagnostic Studies
Audiogram: shown

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Otitis externa may lead to otorrhea and unilateral conductive hearing loss. However, otitis externa is an acute condition in which severe ear pain and intense itching are also expected. Additionally, in otitis externa, otoscopy shows an erythematous and edematous external ear canal rather than a brown irregular mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Acoustic neuroma manifests with unilateral sensorineural, not conductive, hearing loss, and pure tone audiometry reveals an increased threshold for both air and bone conduction. Moreover, a tumor of the vestibular nerve is likely to cause further symptoms, such as vertigo and tinnitus, and does not explain this patient's otorrhea and otoscopic findings.

C) INCORRECT:

Presbycusis manifests gradually with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss rather than unilateral conductive hearing loss; pure tone audiometry would therefore reveal an increased threshold for both air and bone conduction. Furthermore, patients typically present in the sixth decade of life and without otorrhea.
Image Description:

Pure tone audiogram

Both ears show a parallel decrease of air and bone conduction in the higher frequencies. This finding indicates cochlear or retrocochlear damage (often seen in presbycusis).

D) INCORRECT:

Labyrinthitis is caused by inflammation in the inner ear and manifests with unilateral sensorineural, not conductive, hearing loss; pure tone audiometry would therefore show an increased threshold for both air and bone conduction. Furthermore, labyrinthitis typically manifests acutely or subacutely rather than gradually, and severe vertigo and tinnitus are also expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction can manifest with otorrhea and conductive hearing loss. However, in a cerumen-impacted ear, otoscopy shows obstruction of the external auditory canal by a brownish-yellow, waxy plug, and the tympanic membrane is unlikely to be visible.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the external auditory canal

The auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's progressive right-sided conductive hearing loss, painless otorrhea, and irregular mass on otoscopy suggest cholesteatoma of the right ear. Cholesteatomas can be congenital or acquired. Acquired cholesteatomas are classified as primary if caused by chronic negative middle ear pressure (due to eustachian tube dysfunction without middle ear infection) or secondary if caused by past injury to the tympanic membrane (typically due to chronic otitis media). The retraction pocket in the tympanic membrane and the brown, irregular mass are characteristic otoscopic findings of primary acquired cholesteatoma. The typical otoscopic appearance of secondary acquired cholesteatomas is a pearly white mass shining through the intact tympanic membrane.

Surgery is always required to excise cholesteatomas because of the risk of complications of the growing mass, which include the destruction of ear ossicles, perilymph fistula, and facial nerve paralysis.
Image Description:

A cholesteatoma is a collection of keratinizing squamous epithelium that grows from the tympanic membrane or the auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa or mastoid. The presence of abnormal epithelium triggers an inflammatory response that can destroy surrounding structures such as the ossicles.
questions.hint: This patient's audiogram shows a right-sided air-bone gap as a result of an increased auditory threshold in air conduction with normal bone conduction, which is typical for conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman reports a 2-month history of otorrhea and decreased hearing in the left ear. She has a history of frequent bilateral ear infections. She was treated with several sets of tympanostomy tubes as a child. Otoscopic examination reveals the left tympanic membrane is opaque and immobile, with a prominent lateral process of the malleus. Keratinized debris and purulence are evident superiorly, at the pars flaccida. On follow-up examination after a 10-day course of topical antibiotics, the left-ear otorrhea has stopped, but the collection of keratinized debris remains. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In eustachian-tube dysfunction, the eustachian tube fails to equalize pressure between the middle ear and the atmosphere, resulting in negative middle-ear pressure. This can cause recurrent middle-ear infections requiring myringotomy and tube placement, particularly in children. If the dysfunction persists into adulthood, patients may develop chronic otitis media with tympanic-membrane retraction and cholesteatoma, a collection of keratinized debris that builds up in the retraction pockets.

It is important to recognize cholesteatoma when it develops, because it can become superinfected and/or erode the ossicles. On otoscopy, the tympanic membrane will be retracted and appear concave, with a prominent lateral process of the malleus. In addition, the tympanic membrane may be immobile on pneumatic otoscopy. Patients with cholesteatoma should be referred to an otolaryngologist.

Key learning point: When keratinized debris is evident above the tympanic membrane, the most likely diagnosis is cholesteatoma. Cholesteatomas can erode the ossicles and become superinfected.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic eczematoid otitis externa may be accompanied by white debris in the ear canal, but it clears with treatment, leaving the ear drum normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction may initially be associated with an ear infection, but after the infection and wax are cleared, the ear should look normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Fungal otitis externa is associated with whitish debris in the ear canal. It will not clear with antibiotics or antibacterial ear drops. The external auditory canal would appear inflamed, and the tympanic membrane would not be retracted.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute otitis media does not lead to a buildup of keratinized debris in the ear. The tympanic membrane initially appears bulging and convex; it returns to normal after the infection clears.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of otorrhea and decreased hearing in her left ear. She has a history of frequent bilateral ear infections and underwent several sets of tympanostomy tubes as a child. On otoscopic examination, the left tympanic membrane is opaque and immobile, with a prominent lateral process of the malleus. Keratinized debris and purulence are seen superiorly at the pars flaccida. At follow-up after a 10-day course of topical antibiotics, the otorrhea has resolved, but the collection of keratinized debris persists. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction may initially be associated with an ear infection, but after the infection and wax are cleared, the ear should look normal.

B) CORRECT:

In eustachian-tube dysfunction, the eustachian tube fails to equalize pressure between the middle ear and the atmosphere, resulting in negative middle-ear pressure. This can cause recurrent middle-ear infections requiring myringotomy and tube placement, particularly in children. If the dysfunction persists into adulthood, patients may develop chronic otitis media with tympanic-membrane retraction and cholesteatoma, a collection of keratinized debris that builds up in the retraction pockets.

It is important to recognize cholesteatoma when it develops, because it can become superinfected and/or erode the ossicles. On otoscopy, the tympanic membrane will be retracted and appear concave, with a prominent lateral process of the malleus. In addition, the tympanic membrane may be immobile on pneumatic otoscopy. Patients with cholesteatoma should be referred to an otolaryngologist.

Key learning point: When keratinized debris is evident above the tympanic membrane, the most likely diagnosis is cholesteatoma. Cholesteatomas can erode the ossicles and become superinfected.

C) INCORRECT:

Fungal otitis externa is associated with whitish debris in the ear canal. It will not clear with antibiotics or antibacterial ear drops. The external auditory canal would appear inflamed, and the tympanic membrane would not be retracted.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute otitis media does not lead to a buildup of keratinized debris in the ear. The tympanic membrane initially appears bulging and convex; it returns to normal after the infection clears.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic eczematoid otitis externa may be accompanied by white debris in the ear canal, but it clears with treatment, leaving the ear drum normal.
